title: How to Draw a Horse's Blood

steps.headline: Wear long-sleeved clothing, closed-toe shoes, and gloves.
steps.description: This will help you avoid injury and contamination as you take the horse’s blood. You want to protect yourself from the needle. It’s a good idea to also wear protective eyewear, but this isn’t necessary.Variation: If you don’t want to wear gloves, wash your hands with soap and warm water before taking the blood draw.

steps.headline: Tie up your horse.
steps.description: Put your horse into its stall or take it somewhere it's comfortable, such as where you groom it. Then, use a halter and a rope to keep your horse in place. You can also ask a partner to help you keep the horse calm and under control.

steps.headline: Trim the hair on your horse’s neck if necessary.
steps.description: Use clippers to cut the horse’s coat short over the site of the blood draw. This will make it easier for you to clean the site and see the vein to insert the needle. This step is optional, but it can be helpful. You don’t need to remove a large amount of hair. A square that is 3 by 3 inches (7.6 by 7.6 cm) should be sufficient. You may not need to trim the hair if it’s already very short.

steps.headline: Use your non-dominant hand to press down on the bottom of the horse’s neck.
steps.description: Look for the vein that runs down your horse's neck, which is called the jugular. This vein will be in a groove that runs along the lower part of your horse's neck, from its head to its torso. Position your hand over the vein, then apply pressure to show how fast the blood is pumping through the vein. The pressure will also make the vein bulge. Keep your hand pressed against the horse’s neck for the entire process of drawing the blood.Tip: It doesn’t matter which side of the neck you use. There is a jugular vein that runs down both sides of the neck.

steps.headline: Tap lightly on the middle of the jugular vein to make it easier to see.
steps.description: Use your first 3 fingers to firmly tap the vein about halfway up the horse’s neck. Watch for the vein to bulge slightly, which will make it easier to insert your needle. Make sure you keep your non-dominant hand against the lower part of the neck while you do this. The pressure on the lower part of the neck will reduce blood flow, which makes the vein bulge above your hand so that you can see it more easily.

steps.headline: Wipe the draw site with rubbing alcohol to sterilize it.
steps.description: Dampen a piece of gauze with rubbing alcohol, then wipe the horse’s neck where you plan to insert the needle. Press down into the horse’s coat to really clean the area. You don’t want dirt and bacteria to linger on the skin. This will help you avoid accidentally pushing dirt or bacteria into the injection site, which can result in an infection.

steps.headline: Insert a 20-gauge x 1.5 in (3.8 cm) needle at a 20° angle.
steps.description: You may need to adjust the needle a bit to make sure it’s inserted correctly. You’ll know it’s in the right spot when you see the blood start to flow. As an alternative, you can use a vacutainer needle and hub, if you plan to use vacutainers. Your needle should still be about 1.5 in (3.8 cm) long. You can get a needle from your vet, a medical supply store, or online. If the blood spurts or shoots out, remove the needle, because you’ve entered the carotid artery. As you pull out the needle, place a piece of gauze or your finger over the wound for at least 1 minute. Then, check to see if the bleeding has stopped. Continue to apply pressure until you don't see any more bleeding.Tip: Don’t make more than 3 attempts to insert the needle. If you miss 3 times, give the horse a break so it won’t get distressed or develop a large hematoma. Then, you can try again.

steps.headline: Pull back the pump on the syringe to take your blood draw.
steps.description: Slide the pump back slowly as the blood flows into the syringe. Stop when the syringe is full of blood. Break the seal before you insert the syringe into the horse’s vein. Don’t press down on the plunger.

steps.headline: Attach a vacutainer to the syringe hub, if you’re using one.
steps.description: Stabilize the needle, then use your dominant hand to gently push the vacutainer onto the syringe. Once it’s attached, blood will fill the vacutainer. A vacutainer is a tube that’s used to collect blood. You can find them at a vet supply store, a drug store, or online. It’s okay to use vacutainers made for humans. If you want to take several samples, simply remove the full vacutainer and insert a new one.

steps.headline: Remove the vacutainer before pulling out the needle, if you used one.
steps.description: Carefully pull the vacutainer off of the hub. Set it aside on a stable surface while you withdraw the needle and tend to the site. If you remove the needle before you detach the vacutainer, you’ll release the vacuum seal.

steps.headline: Remove the needle and press your finger over the injection site for 1 minute.
steps.description: Place your finger above the needle, then slowly slide the needle out of the vein. As you do so, quickly move your finger over the injection site. Apply firm pressure to the site to stop the bleeding. As an alternative, you can hold a piece of gauze over the injection site.

steps.headline: Dispose of the needle in a leak-proof, puncture-resistant container.
steps.description: Used needles can be hazardous if they aren’t disposed of properly. Choose a container that is secure so you know the needle can't fall out. Additionally, label your disposal container so people know it has sharps inside it. For example, you might place it in a sturdy plastic container that has a lid.

steps.headline: Label the sample with the horse’s ID.
steps.description: Use a permanent marker to fill out the label on the vacutainer with the horse’s name and the date. If your lab requires additional information, make sure to provide this, as well.

steps.headline: Refrigerate the sample until you’re ready to send it the lab.
steps.description: Keeping the sample cool will prevent it from getting ruined. However, you still need to get it tested as soon as possible to ensure valid results.Tip: If you’re shipping your sample to a lab, make sure you pack it in ice before shipping it.

text: Attending to Safety Concerns Wear long-sleeved clothing, closed-toe shoes, and gloves. This will help you avoid injury and contamination as you take the horse’s blood. You want to protect yourself from the needle. It’s a good idea to also wear protective eyewear, but this isn’t necessary.Variation: If you don’t want to wear gloves, wash your hands with soap and warm water before taking the blood draw. Tie up your horse. Put your horse into its stall or take it somewhere it's comfortable, such as where you groom it. Then, use a halter and a rope to keep your horse in place. You can also ask a partner to help you keep the horse calm and under control. Trim the hair on your horse’s neck if necessary. Use clippers to cut the horse’s coat short over the site of the blood draw. This will make it easier for you to clean the site and see the vein to insert the needle. This step is optional, but it can be helpful. You don’t need to remove a large amount of hair. A square that is 3 by 3 inches (7.6 by 7.6 cm) should be sufficient. You may not need to trim the hair if it’s already very short. Locating the Jugular Vein Use your non-dominant hand to press down on the bottom of the horse’s neck. Look for the vein that runs down your horse's neck, which is called the jugular. This vein will be in a groove that runs along the lower part of your horse's neck, from its head to its torso. Position your hand over the vein, then apply pressure to show how fast the blood is pumping through the vein. The pressure will also make the vein bulge. Keep your hand pressed against the horse’s neck for the entire process of drawing the blood.Tip: It doesn’t matter which side of the neck you use. There is a jugular vein that runs down both sides of the neck. Tap lightly on the middle of the jugular vein to make it easier to see. Use your first 3 fingers to firmly tap the vein about halfway up the horse’s neck. Watch for the vein to bulge slightly, which will make it easier to insert your needle. Make sure you keep your non-dominant hand against the lower part of the neck while you do this. The pressure on the lower part of the neck will reduce blood flow, which makes the vein bulge above your hand so that you can see it more easily. Wipe the draw site with rubbing alcohol to sterilize it. Dampen a piece of gauze with rubbing alcohol, then wipe the horse’s neck where you plan to insert the needle. Press down into the horse’s coat to really clean the area. You don’t want dirt and bacteria to linger on the skin. This will help you avoid accidentally pushing dirt or bacteria into the injection site, which can result in an infection. Taking the Sample Insert a 20-gauge x 1.5 in (3.8 cm) needle at a 20° angle. You may need to adjust the needle a bit to make sure it’s inserted correctly. You’ll know it’s in the right spot when you see the blood start to flow. As an alternative, you can use a vacutainer needle and hub, if you plan to use vacutainers. Your needle should still be about 1.5 in (3.8 cm) long. You can get a needle from your vet, a medical supply store, or online. If the blood spurts or shoots out, remove the needle, because you’ve entered the carotid artery. As you pull out the needle, place a piece of gauze or your finger over the wound for at least 1 minute. Then, check to see if the bleeding has stopped. Continue to apply pressure until you don't see any more bleeding.Tip: Don’t make more than 3 attempts to insert the needle. If you miss 3 times, give the horse a break so it won’t get distressed or develop a large hematoma. Then, you can try again. Pull back the pump on the syringe to take your blood draw. Slide the pump back slowly as the blood flows into the syringe. Stop when the syringe is full of blood. Break the seal before you insert the syringe into the horse’s vein. Don’t press down on the plunger. Attach a vacutainer to the syringe hub, if you’re using one. Stabilize the needle, then use your dominant hand to gently push the vacutainer onto the syringe. Once it’s attached, blood will fill the vacutainer. A vacutainer is a tube that’s used to collect blood. You can find them at a vet supply store, a drug store, or online. It’s okay to use vacutainers made for humans. If you want to take several samples, simply remove the full vacutainer and insert a new one. Finishing the Blood Draw Remove the vacutainer before pulling out the needle, if you used one. Carefully pull the vacutainer off of the hub. Set it aside on a stable surface while you withdraw the needle and tend to the site. If you remove the needle before you detach the vacutainer, you’ll release the vacuum seal. Remove the needle and press your finger over the injection site for 1 minute. Place your finger above the needle, then slowly slide the needle out of the vein. As you do so, quickly move your finger over the injection site. Apply firm pressure to the site to stop the bleeding. As an alternative, you can hold a piece of gauze over the injection site. Dispose of the needle in a leak-proof, puncture-resistant container. Used needles can be hazardous if they aren’t disposed of properly. Choose a container that is secure so you know the needle can't fall out. Additionally, label your disposal container so people know it has sharps inside it. For example, you might place it in a sturdy plastic container that has a lid. Label the sample with the horse’s ID. Use a permanent marker to fill out the label on the vacutainer with the horse’s name and the date. If your lab requires additional information, make sure to provide this, as well. Refrigerate the sample until you’re ready to send it the lab. Keeping the sample cool will prevent it from getting ruined. However, you still need to get it tested as soon as possible to ensure valid results.Tip: If you’re shipping your sample to a lab, make sure you pack it in ice before shipping it.

This will help you avoid injury and contamination as you take the horse’s blood.
You want to protect yourself from the needle.
It’s a good idea to also wear protective eyewear, but this isn’t necessary.Variation: If you don’t want to wear gloves, wash your hands with soap and warm water before taking the blood draw.
Tie up your horse.
Put your horse into its stall or take it somewhere it's comfortable, such as where you groom it.
Then, use a halter and a rope to keep your horse in place.
You can also ask a partner to help you keep the horse calm and under control.
Trim the hair on your horse’s neck if necessary.
Use clippers to cut the horse’s coat short over the site of the blood draw.
This will make it easier for you to clean the site and see the vein to insert the needle.
This step is optional, but it can be helpful.
You don’t need to remove a large amount of hair.
A square that is 3 by 3 inches (7.6 by 7.6 cm) should be sufficient.
You may not need to trim the hair if it’s already very short.
Locating the Jugular Vein Use your non-dominant hand to press down on the bottom of the horse’s neck.
Look for the vein that runs down your horse's neck, which is called the jugular.
This vein will be in a groove that runs along the lower part of your horse's neck, from its head to its torso.
Position your hand over the vein, then apply pressure to show how fast the blood is pumping through the vein.
The pressure will also make the vein bulge.
Keep your hand pressed against the horse’s neck for the entire process of drawing the blood.Tip: It doesn’t matter which side of the neck you use.
There is a jugular vein that runs down both sides of the neck.
Tap lightly on the middle of the jugular vein to make it easier to see.
Use your first 3 fingers to firmly tap the vein about halfway up the horse’s neck.
Watch for the vein to bulge slightly, which will make it easier to insert your needle.
Make sure you keep your non-dominant hand against the lower part of the neck while you do this.
The pressure on the lower part of the neck will reduce blood flow, which makes the vein bulge above your hand so that you can see it more easily.
Wipe the draw site with rubbing alcohol to sterilize it.
Dampen a piece of gauze with rubbing alcohol, then wipe the horse’s neck where you plan to insert the needle.
Press down into the horse’s coat to really clean the area.
You don’t want dirt and bacteria to linger on the skin.
This will help you avoid accidentally pushing dirt or bacteria into the injection site, which can result in an infection.
Taking the Sample Insert a 20-gauge x 1.5 in (3.8 cm) needle at a 20° angle.
You may need to adjust the needle a bit to make sure it’s inserted correctly.
You’ll know it’s in the right spot when you see the blood start to flow.
As an alternative, you can use a vacutainer needle and hub, if you plan to use vacutainers.
Your needle should still be about 1.5 in (3.8 cm) long.
You can get a needle from your vet, a medical supply store, or online.
If the blood spurts or shoots out, remove the needle, because you’ve entered the carotid artery.
As you pull out the needle, place a piece of gauze or your finger over the wound for at least 1 minute.
Then, check to see if the bleeding has stopped.
Continue to apply pressure until you don't see any more bleeding.Tip: Don’t make more than 3 attempts to insert the needle.
If you miss 3 times, give the horse a break so it won’t get distressed or develop a large hematoma.
Then, you can try again.
Pull back the pump on the syringe to take your blood draw.
Slide the pump back slowly as the blood flows into the syringe.
Stop when the syringe is full of blood.
Break the seal before you insert the syringe into the horse’s vein.
Don’t press down on the plunger.
Attach a vacutainer to the syringe hub, if you’re using one.
Stabilize the needle, then use your dominant hand to gently push the vacutainer onto the syringe.
Once it’s attached, blood will fill the vacutainer.
A vacutainer is a tube that’s used to collect blood.
You can find them at a vet supply store, a drug store, or online.
It’s okay to use vacutainers made for humans.
If you want to take several samples, simply remove the full vacutainer and insert a new one.
Finishing the Blood Draw Remove the vacutainer before pulling out the needle, if you used one.
Carefully pull the vacutainer off of the hub.
Set it aside on a stable surface while you withdraw the needle and tend to the site.
If you remove the needle before you detach the vacutainer, you’ll release the vacuum seal.
Remove the needle and press your finger over the injection site for 1 minute.
Place your finger above the needle, then slowly slide the needle out of the vein.
As you do so, quickly move your finger over the injection site.
Apply firm pressure to the site to stop the bleeding.
As an alternative, you can hold a piece of gauze over the injection site.
Dispose of the needle in a leak-proof, puncture-resistant container.
Used needles can be hazardous if they aren’t disposed of properly.
Choose a container that is secure so you know the needle can't fall out.
Additionally, label your disposal container so people know it has sharps inside it.
For example, you might place it in a sturdy plastic container that has a lid.
Label the sample with the horse’s ID.
Use a permanent marker to fill out the label on the vacutainer with the horse’s name and the date.
If your lab requires additional information, make sure to provide this, as well.
Refrigerate the sample until you’re ready to send it the lab.
Keeping the sample cool will prevent it from getting ruined.
However, you still need to get it tested as soon as possible to ensure valid results.Tip: If you’re shipping your sample to a lab, make sure you pack it in ice before shipping it.
